School of Civil Engineering Purdue University 550 Stadium Mall Dr. West Lafayette IN 47907 USA There is an increasing number of recent studies about personalized thermal preferences and controls in office buildings. Data collection from occupants in real buildings is necessary for training and updating models. However, sufficient quantity and quality of data are required for developing reliable models, along with optimal model complexity, efficient updating modes and robust evaluation metrics. Therefore, long-term collection of occupant feedback is often needed, which might be intrusive and impractical. This paper presents a Bayesian modeling approach which incorporates voluntary feedback data (comfort-related responses), collected via participatory interfaces, along with requested feedback data, into the personal thermal preference learning framework. This is achieved by explicitly considering occupants’ participation –a type of behavior –in the model structure, i.e., integration of thermal preference-related feedback and occupant behavior. The approach was evaluated with two different datasets collected from two experimental setups with human test-subjects. A smart feedback request algorithm was developed, which determines whether to request feedback at any given time based on the quantified value (i.e., information gain) of the request. The value was computed using the expected Kullback-Leibler divergence between the current and updated posterior parameter distributions. In addition, a simulation study was conducted to evaluate the performance of the algorithm. The results show that the new algorithm learns individual thermal preferences with reduced feedback requests, i.e., effective but less-intrusive. Requesting occupant feedback only when truly needed is important for smart and practical human-centered HVAC operation. Keywords Bayesian modeling Occupant behaviour Personalized environments Thermal preferences Human-in-the-loop Occupant centric Personalized comfort User interface 1 Introduction Operation of typical heating, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC) systems has been based on well-known thermal comfort models, e.g., Fanger's predicted mean vote (PMV) model [1]. However, HVAC configurations are not setup to deliver personal comfort, but instead seek to satisfy the needs of the “average” occupant. Subsequently, HVAC operation that ignores individual differences has been indicated as a significant factor causing thermal dissatisfaction in buildings [1–6]. To resolve the problem, HVAC systems and controls should have learning and self-tuning features to provide customized indoor thermal environments, i.e., systems need to learn what thermal conditions their actual occupants prefer, from the occupants' feedback or behaviors, and subsequently, automatically tune their operation to provide the preferred conditions. The potential of such systems to improve occupant satisfaction and energy efficiency has been demonstrated in recent studies [7–16]. For example, Feldmeier and Paradiso [7] showed that their smart HVAV control system reduced the number of discomfort responses while also reducing energy consumption by 24%. Methods for learning individual occupants' thermal comfort, i.e., training personalized comfort models, have been explored extensively with the development of sensing, machine learning, and computing technologies. Researchers have examined the effectiveness and efficiency of various machine learning/data-driven algorithms and input variables, based on thermal comfort-related responses collected from people [7–10,12,14,15,17–29]. However, there has been a lack of discussion regarding methods of collecting the feedback responses in real buildings, for example: how feasible or intrusive a method is; how effective a method is in collecting sufficient data; how reliable data can be collected with a method; and how reliable a machine learning algorithm is in developing a personalized model with data collected with a specific method. Thermal comfort is defined as a condition of mind that expresses satisfaction with the thermal environment [30]; thus, the only way we can measure it is by surveying occupants [31], assuming that their responses are reliable. In this context, to minimize the risk of sampling bias [32] and subsequently develop unbiased personalized comfort models, requesting occupants' responses randomly or regularly would be preferred [17–21,24,26]. However, frequent response requests are intrusive and thus not feasible in real buildings, especially if continuous data collection and model updating are required to deal with changes in one's thermal comfort over time. On the contrary, if we decrease the frequency, it would take a long time to collect enough data to train personalized comfort models. To resolve this practical issue, occupants can voluntarily report their state of thermal comfort using participatory user interfaces [7,8,12,15]. Although this alternative method seems practical for real-world applications, occupants' participation, a type of behavior, could be affected by multiple factors; consequently, there is a high risk of sampling bias. For example, people would actively participate and provide their feedback if they are uncomfortable, believing that the feedback could improve the thermal conditions. On the contrary, if they are satisfied with the conditions, they might not be as responsive. If we train a predictive model with the biased data without any treatment, because of the lack of satisfaction/comfort/neutral responses, the predictive probability (or corresponding score) of satisfaction/comfort/neutral will keep decreasing as we feed more data, i.e., additional data cannot guarantee a better model. In Ref. [8,15], researchers assumed that occupants were satisfied/comfortable if there was no participation for a while and added hypothetical data points in their training dataset. However, it is possible that occupants may not (or forget to) participate even though they are not satisfied because of their workload [15]. Also, there are other factors (e.g., the ease of interface use, or the level of expectation that the system will adapt to their response) making it difficult to develop generalizable heuristic rules for participatory data collection [12]. Moreover, the proposed rules cannot distinguish between the effects of one's thermal preference and the level of one's activity in using the participatory interface on the data distribution. Hence, if we operate an HVAC system serving a shared space, e.g., an open-plan office, with personalized comfort models based on one of the rules, the thermal condition will be biased towards the thermal preference of active occupants, which may not be the best option. In addition, using a participatory interface does not necessarily guarantee that we can collect enough data to learn one's thermal preference. For example, Sanguinetti [33] reported that 77% of participants submitted only 1–2 votes through the participatory interface for six months. In this study, we present a Bayesian modeling approach and a participatory user interface which allow incorporating voluntary feedback data (comfort-related responses), along with requested feedback data, into the thermal preference learning framework. The incorporation is done by explicitly considering occupants' participation –a type of behavior –in the model. We evaluate the approach with two different datasets collected from two experimental setups with human subjects. Since the approach allows using both requested and participatory responses, we can (i) mainly rely on participatory responses and (ii) additionally request responses only when they are truly needed, to learn one's thermal preference effectively and less intrusively. To realize this, we propose a smart occupant feedback request algorithm, which determines whether to request feedback at each moment based on the quantified value of the request. Finally, to evaluate the algorithm, a simulation study was conducted with various scenarios. 2 Methodology Section 2 consists of four parts. Section 2.1 describes an experiment conducted to collect thermal preference responses from 5 human subjects. In the experiment, two different setups were used. In the first setup, the subjects were requested to provide their preference responses every 30 min, i.e., collection of requested responses. In the second setup, they were asked to provide their responses whenever they want through a participatory interface, i.e., collection of participatory responses. Section 2.2 describes two model structures proposed for learning individual occupants' thermal preferences, i.e., personalized comfort models. The first model structure (Eqs. (1)–(3)) is for learning with requested responses; the second (Eqs. (6) and (7) in addition to Eqs. (1)–(3)) is for learning with participatory responses. The other equations in this section are included to help readers who are interested in the Bayesian model training, and subsequently, to ensure the reproducibility of the work. To deliver the concepts behind the model structures clearly, the structures are simplified as much as they can be without losing the ability to learn personal preference, feasibility, and generalizability. Please note that previous studies (e.g. Ref. [7,18,22]) showed that a personal comfort model with a simple structure and limited set of inputs (e.g., air temperature as the only input) could predict the individual's comfort reasonably well. Section 2.3 explains how to learn each occupant's thermal preference with both requested and participatory responses with the second model structure proposed in Section 2.2. Subsequently, a smart request algorithm is presented, which determines whether to request feedback at each moment based on the quantified value of the request. The algorithm allows to collect sufficient data to learn one's thermal preference with a reduced number of feedback requests, i.e., effective but less-intrusive. Section 2.4 presents a simulation study designed to demonstrate how the smart request algorithm works. 2.1 Experimental study To collect data for the study, an experiment was conducted with five human subjects (four male, one female, all graduate students, 22–35 years old) using three identical perimeter south-facing private offices (3.3 m × 3.7 m × 3.2 m high) in West Lafayette, Indiana (Fig. 1 ) in March and April 2019. Each office has one exterior curtain wall façade with the following properties: 54% window-to-wall ratio, high-performance glazing with selective low-emissivity coating (normal visible transmittance: 70%, solar transmittance: 33%). The thermal and visual environment is controlled in each office with a VAV system, motorized shades, and dimmable electric lights. All building systems are monitored, controlled and automated though a commercial building management system (BMS). During the experiments, the dimming level of the electric lights was set at 100% and the shade position at 25% (eye height). In this way, visual environment impacts on thermal preferences were minimized (recent studies [45,46] showed that human perception might be affected by interactions between the different domains of indoor environment). During the experiment, the subjects performed their usual workload (computer-related work, reading, writing, etc.) and wore similar clothing each day they participated. In each room, one monitor was designated for a simple user-interface (Fig. 2 ) that the subjects used to report their thermal preference by selecting one of the following three answers: “I prefer warmer”/“I prefer cooler”/“I am satisfied with current thermal conditions.” The study was approved by the Institutional Review Board (IRB Protocol #: 1503015873). Two shielded T-type thermocouples were installed on the left and right side of the sitting location to measure (with 1-min time interval) the air temperature and the average value was used. A wireless data acquisition system (National Instrument system consists of NIcRio-3024, NI9795, and WSN-3212) was deployed for the data collection. The globe temperature, relative humidity, and local air speed were also measured but were not used in the analysis. In the experiment, two different setups were used to collect two datasets from each person, which are called “requested” and “participatory,” respectively. In the requested setup, the interface was activated if the subject stayed in the room for 30 min and the subjects were requested to report their thermal preference. Once they submitted a response, the 30-min timer was reset, the interface became deactivated, and the room air temperature setpoint was changed to the next value in one of the pre-determined schedules listed in Table 1 . If the subject took a short break, the timer was reset when they came back, but the setpoint was maintained. The subjects were asked to report their thermal preference six times before and after lunch. Each subject participated in this setup for four days and experienced all the schedules. For each occupant, data collected in this setup is called a requested dataset. In the participatory setup, the interface was always activated (without any survey request), and the subjects could report their thermal preference voluntarily, if and whenever they wanted. In this setup, the air temperature setpoint was changed based on the subject's thermal preference responses with the following rule (the subjects were informed that the room air temperature would be adjusted based on their responses without explaining the details): • “prefer cooler” → decrease by 0.5 °C • “satisfied” → no setpoint change • “prefer warmer” → increase by 0.5 °C To avoid frequent temperature changes, responses submitted within 20 min after entering the room or after the previous response were ignored. The subjects were asked to stay in the room for 3 h before and after lunch. Different initial temperature setpoints (i.e., 25, 22.5, 20 °C) were applied at the beginning of each session to avoid bias as much as possible. Each subject participated for three days (six sessions) in this setup and experienced each initial temperature setpoint twice. For each occupant, data collected in this setup is called a participatory dataset. 2.2 Personalized thermal preference models using requested and participatory data Two different model structures are considered for developing personalized thermal preference models with the requested and participatory datasets (Fig. 3 ), respectively. For the first one, we use the linear ordered probit model [34] considering the obvious order between the thermal preference classes: “prefer warmer”, “satisfied”, and “prefer cooler”. In other words, we assume that there is a latent quantity, l , which is hidden and cannot be measured or observed directly, representing the thermal state of one's body and mind. If this quantity is below a certain threshold, τ 1 , one will prefer warmer conditions; if it is above a certain threshold, τ 2 , one will prefer cooler conditions; and in between, one will be satisfied. This quantity is affected by multiple factors, e.g., air temperature, mean radiant temperature, air speed, metabolic rate, etc. as shown in Fig. 3 (Model 1). In this study, to illustrate the concept in a relatively simple manner, a linear relationship between air temperature, t a , and the latent quantity, l , is assumed, and the aggregated effect of all the unconsidered factors on the latent quantity, h l , is assumed to follow a standard normal distribution, i.e., l = f ( t ) + h l , where t is the scaled air temperature, f ( t ) = β 0 + β 1 t , p ( h l ) = N ( h l | 0,1 ) , N ( ⋅ | μ , σ 2 ) is the PDF of a normal distribution with mean μ and variance σ 2 . In other words, p ( l | t , β 0 , β 1 ) = N ( l | f ( t ) , 1 ) . The air temperature is scaled as t = ( t a − t mean ) / t std , where t mean and t std are the mean and standard deviation of measured temperature values in the particular setup. The quantity representing the thermal state of one's body and mind, l , should have an interpretable meaning (i.e., positive, negative, and zero values mean “preferring cooler”, “preferring warmer”, and “satisfied” states, respectively), and its magnitude, i.e., the absolute value, represents the level of significance. To this end, we set τ 1 = − τ 2 . Then, the probability of the person being satisfied is maximized at the “satisfied” state, l = 0 . Subsequently, the probability for the thermal preference, y , given the scaled air temperature, is modelled as: (1) p ( y = 1 | t , β , τ ) : = P [ l < − τ | t , β , τ ] = Φ ( − τ − f ( t ) ) (2) p ( y = 0 | t , β , τ ) : = P [ − τ ≤ l ≤ τ | t , β , τ ] = Φ ( τ − f ( t ) ) − Φ ( − τ − f ( t ) ) (3) p ( y = − 1 | t , β , τ ) : = P [ τ < l | t , β , τ ] = 1 − Φ ( τ − f ( t ) ) where β = ( β 0 , β 1 ) , τ = τ 2 , Φ ( ⋅ ) is the CDF of the standard normal distribution and y = − 1,0,1 represent “prefer cooler”, “satisfied,” and “prefer warmer”, respectively (Fig. 4 ). One's thermal preference, y , is a latent state which we cannot observe normally. However, by requesting a thermal preference response, y r , we observe the latent state, y , indirectly. The posterior parameter distribution of the model can be written as: (4) p ( β , τ | y r , t ) ∝ p ( y r | t , β , τ ) p ( β , τ ) where y r = ( y r ( 1 ) , … , y r ( N ) ) and t = ( t ( 1 ) , … , t ( N ) ) , i.e., training dataset of N observations. The likelihood can be decomposed as: (5) p ( y r | t , β , τ ) = ∏ i = 1 N p ( y r ( i ) | t ( i ) , β , τ ) which we can calculate with Eqs. (1)–(3). The key point in this model is that we consider the latent quantity, l , which is assumed to determine the occupant's thermal preference. This quantity plays a key role also in the second model structure explained next. The second model structure in this study (Model 2 in Fig. 3) is designed to develop one's personalized preference model with participatory preference responses, y p . As discussed in the introduction, occupants' participation, a type of behavior, could be affected by multiple factors other than their preference; consequently, there is a high risk of sampling bias. To resolve this issue, we explicitly consider occupants' participation in this model structure. Again, we assign y p = − 1,0,1 to “prefer cooler”, “satisfied,” and “prefer warmer” responses, respectively. Relationships between t , l , and h l are the same as described above. Now, however, the variable y has one more class, y = 2 , representing instances of no thermal preference response in the participatory scenario. To properly model y p , which is one's participatory preference responses plus instances of no response, we need to think about causal factors triggering one's participation, v . Some studies [8,15] suggest that occupants' thermal comfort-related behavior is mainly triggered by their dissatisfaction/discomfort with the thermal environments. However, there could be other reasons triggering one's participation, and these are independently introduced in the models as follows: • If one is not satisfied with the current thermal condition, i.e., | l | > τ , there is a non-zero probability of the occupant participating because of the dissatisfaction. The probability increases as the magnitude of the occupant's thermal state, | l | , increases. • There are other factors [15] that influence this dissatisfaction-triggered participation, e.g., level of workload or one's expectation that the thermal environments might be improved by the behavior. The influence of these other factors, h v 1 , follows a zero-mean normal distribution, p ( h v 1 | σ v ) = N ( h v 1 | 0 , σ v 2 ) . • The aggregated effect of (i) the magnitude of one's thermal state, l , and (ii) the influence of the other factors, h v 1 , determines one's dissatisfaction-triggered participation. We model the aggregated effect as − | l | + h v 1 . Other functional forms, instead of using the absolute value, | l | , can be explored. • If the aggregated effect is below a certain threshold, δ , one will participate because of the dissatisfaction. • Other reasons, h v 2 , rather than the thermal dissatisfaction could trigger one's participation. However, since we do not have detailed information about the other reasons, we directly model the probability of one's participation triggered by the other reasons as a Bernoulli distribution. • If one participates, he or she will submit a response that reflects his or her thermal preference, y p = y ; otherwise, there will be no response, y p = 2 . Therefore, the probability of one's participation (v) is expressed mathematically as: (6) p ( v = 0 | y , l , δ , σ v , q ) : = { ( 1 − q ) , y = 0 ( 1 − Φ ( δ + | l | σ v ) ) ( 1 − q ) , y ≠ 0 (7) p ( v = 1 | y , l , δ , σ v , q ) = 1 − p ( v = 0 | y , l , δ , σ v , q ) where q represents the probability that non-dissatisfaction reasons trigger one's participation and 0 < q < 1 . Note that there are six model parameters in total. The first three: β 0 , β 1 , and τ , explain one's thermal preference; the other three: δ , σ v , and q , represent how active the person is in using the interface and how much aleatoric uncertainty exists in the prediction of the participation. These parameters are designed to be estimated with data from each individual occupant using a certain interface under a certain contextual setting. Therefore, we expect that the model can be applied to various settings, with different interface designs and control strategies. The posterior distribution of this model can be written as: (8) p ( θ , y , l | y p , v , t ) ∝ p ( y p | v , y , l , t , θ ) p ( v | y , l , t , θ ) p ( y | l , t , θ ) p ( l | t , θ ) p ( θ ) where y p = ( y p ( 1 ) , … , y p ( N ) ) , v = ( v ( 1 ) , … , v ( N ) ) , t = ( t ( 1 ) , … , t ( N ) ) , y = ( y ( 1 ) , … , y ( N ) ) , l = ( l ( 1 ) , … , l ( N ) ) , and θ = ( β , τ , δ , σ v , q ) . The right hand side of Eq. (8) can be decomposed as: (9) ∏ i = 1 N p ( y p ( i ) | v ( i ) , y ( i ) , l ( i ) , t ( i ) , θ ) p ( v ( i ) | y ( i ) , l ( i ) , t ( i ) , θ ) p ( y ( i ) | l ( i ) , t ( i ) , θ ) p ( l ( i ) | t ( i ) , θ ) p ( θ ) Here, since we are interested in the posterior parameter distribution, p ( θ | y p , t ) , to reduce the computational cost, we marginalize v , y , and l out from the above equation as: (10) p ( θ | y p , t ) ∝ ∫ ∑ v ∑ y p ( y p | v , y , l , t , θ ) p ( v | y , l , t , θ ) p ( y | l , t , θ ) p ( l | t , θ ) p ( θ ) d l = ∏ i = 1 N p ( y p ( i ) | t ( i ) , θ ) p ( θ ) where: (11) p ( y p = 1 | t , θ ) = ∫ − ∞ − τ p ( v = 1 | y = 1 , l , θ ) p ( l | t , θ ) d l (12) p ( y p = 0 | t , θ ) = ∫ − τ τ p ( v = 1 | y = 0 , l , θ ) p ( l | t , θ ) d l (13) p ( y p = − 1 | t , θ ) = ∫ τ ∞ p ( v = 1 | y = − 1 , l , θ ) p ( l | t , θ ) d l (14) p ( y p = 2 | t , θ ) = ∫ − ∞ − τ p ( v = 0 | y = 1 , l , θ ) p ( l | t , θ ) d l + ∫ − τ τ p ( v = 0 | y = 0 , l , θ ) p ( l | t , θ ) d l + ∫ τ ∞ p ( v = 0 | y = − 1 , l , θ ) p ( l | t , θ ) d l To estimate the posterior, we need to set the prior distribution, p ( θ ) . For p ( β 0 ) , p ( β 1 ) , and p ( τ ) , we first consider our prior knowledge: (i) β 0 would be around zero since the probability of satisfaction would be maximized between 20 and 26 °C (discovered in our previous studies [28,35]); (ii) β 1 should be positive considering the obvious order between the thermal preferences. Then, to choose a specific distribution reflecting our prior knowledge, we tested different distributions visually by plotting the predictive probability distributions with some samples from them (Fig. 5 ). Finally, we set p ( β 0 ) = N ( β 0 | 0 , 2 . 5 2 ) , p ( β 1 ) = Gamma ( β 1 | 2,1.5 ) , and p ( τ ) = Gamma ( τ | 4,4 ) , where Gamma ( ⋅ | α , β ) represents the PDF of a gamma distribution with shape α and rate β parameters. For p ( q ) , we use p ( q ) = U ( ⋅ | 0,1 ) , where U ( ⋅ | a , b ) is the PDF of a continuous uniform distribution with upper and lower bounds, a , b , i.e., no informative prior knowledge. For p ( δ ) , we expect that δ would be close to − τ . However, since we do not have strong prior knowledge, we employ a hierarchical Bayesian approach and assign p ( δ | τ , σ δ ) = N ( δ | − τ , σ δ 2 ) and p ( σ δ ) = E ( σ δ | 10 − 1 ) , where E ( ⋅ | λ ) represents the PDF of an exponential distribution with a rate λ parameter, considering the scale of l . Similarly, for p ( σ v ) , we assign p ( σ v | η ) = E ( σ v | η − 1 ) and p ( η ) = E ( η | 10 − 1 ) . To estimate the posterior distribution of the model parameters, which is intractable analytically, we use sequential Monte Carlo (SMC), described in Appendix A, which is more efficient than standard Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) [36]. Table 2 shows the SMC settings used in this study, which provided consistent results in multiple trainings with a reasonable computational cost. Personalized models should be updated continuously as feedback responses are collected. In this regard, the standard way of updating is re-training the model with all the data we have repeatedly. However, even though SMC is efficient, the re-training computational cost will increase rapidly as the dataset size increases and might become intractable for local computers in real buildings [35]. Hence, to resolve this problem, we developed a method for an efficient Bayesian model update. Suppose that we already had samples approximating the posterior parameter distribution, p ( θ | D ) , where D represents the training dataset including thermal preference responses and temperature data. We receive an additional data point, ( y new , t new ) , and want to update the posterior with this data point, i.e., estimating p ( θ | D , y new , t new ) . If we rearrange the equation as: (15) p ( θ | D , y new , t new ) ∝ p ( y new | t new , θ ) p ( θ | D ) then we can estimate the posterior with the likelihood of the new data point using the previous posterior, p ( θ | D ) , as the prior. In other words, if we use the previous posterior directly in the estimation, we can update the model very efficiently. To this end, we use the samples approximating p ( θ | D ) at the first SMC step and modify the likelihood part correspondingly. We describe the mathematical details in Appendix B. It is worth noting that this method can also be used in other Bayesian model estimation problems where an efficient model update is needed. 2.3 Smart feedback request algorithm: quantifying the value of information gain As shown in Fig. 3, Model 1 is nested in Model 2, and they share three parameters: β 0 , β 1 , τ , which are used to predict the probability of one's preference. In other words, we can construct an augmented model structure to learn one's thermal preference with both requested and participatory preference responses. The likelihood of the augmented model is: (16) p ( y obs | t , θ , r ) = ∏ i = 1 N p ( y obs ( i ) | t ( i ) , r ( i ) , θ ) where y obs = ( y obs ( 1 ) , … , y obs ( N ) ) includes both requested and participatory preference responses, r = ( r ( 1 ) , … , r ( N ) ) , and r ( i ) = 0 or 1 indicate whether y obs ( i ) is participatory or requested, respectively. Since frequent response requests are intrusive, requesting regularly or randomly is not efficient nor effective. The ideal way would be (i) to mainly rely on participatory responses and (ii) to additionally request responses only when they are truly needed. Here, the question is how to quantify the value (importance) of requesting a response (information gain) at a given moment (under specific conditions). The value of information gain at any given condition varies with our current state of knowledge regarding the occupant's thermal preference. For example, if the current temperature is 30 °C, and we are already quite certain that the occupant will prefer a cooler temperature, an additional requested response at that moment will not improve our state of knowledge –therefore, the value of a request would be zero, and we do not need to disturb the occupant. The theory of Bayesian experimental design provides a general probability-theoretical framework for such a problem, which is based on the theory for decision-making under uncertainty [37]. The objective of Bayesian experimental design is to maximize the expected utility/value when designing the experiment. In our case, we want to decide whether to request feedback or not, i.e., designing an experiment, to maximize the information gain (utility). The utility can involve the cost of performing the experiment. More specifically, assume that we have a personalized model trained with a dataset, D = { y obs , t , r } , collected from a person, i.e., the posterior parameter distribution, p ( θ | D ) . At the next instance, we want to quantify the expected information gain with/without a feedback request. We use the Kullback–Leibler divergence ( D K L ) between p ( θ | D ) and p ( θ | D , y new , t new , r new ) as the measure for the information gain: (17) D K L ( p ( θ | D , d new ) | | p ( θ | D ) ) = ∫ p ( θ | D , d new ) log p ( θ | D , d new ) p ( θ | D ) d θ where d new = ( y new , t new , r new ) are the data points of the next instance. In statistics, the Kullback–Leibler divergence (also called relative entropy) shows how one distribution is different from another. In other words, the quantity shows how different the updated and the original posterior distributions are [38]. D K L is widely used Bayesian experimental design approaches [39]. Since we cannot know y new before we observe it, we use the expected D K L , (18) U ( t new , r new ) = E y [ D K L ( p ( θ | D , d new ) | | p ( θ | D ) ) ] = ∫ ∑ y new p ( θ | D , d new ) p ( y new | D , t new , r new ) log p ( θ | D , d new ) p ( θ | D ) d θ The estimation of this quantity is computationally easy with SMC. We described how we estimate this quantity in Appendix C. Based on U ( t new , r new = 0 ) and U ( t new , r new = 1 ) , we can decide whether to request a response or not, i.e., a smart request algorithm. In this study, we make decisions by simply comparing the magnitude of the two quantities: if U ( t new , r new = 1 ) > U ( t new , r new = 0 ) , request a response, otherwise, do not request. Note that other quantities, e.g., D K L between the updated and original predictive probability distributions, could also be used to quantify the value of a data point. In addition, the cost of requesting a response, e.g., how intrusive/disturbing it is, can be considered to make decisions. 2.4 A simulation process to evaluate the proposed feedback request algorithm To evaluate the effectiveness of the smart feedback request algorithm, we conducted a simulation study with a synthetic occupant which provides thermal preference responses. The synthetic occupant is represented by the augmented model (Eq. (15)) with parameters, θ true , pre-determined by us. In Section 3.3 (Simulation Results), we describe what values we used for the simulation and how we selected the values. In the simulation, the parameters are assumed to be unknown. Fig. 6 presents the simulation steps and procedure. For the second process, i.e., computing the temperature control range with a personalized preference model, we use the method proposed in Ref. [16]. Details of the method are described in Appendix D for reference. With a control range, there are multiple different ways to actually operate an HVAC system, e.g., two step on-off control (bang-bang control), single setpoint tracking, predictive optimal control. In the third process, to make the simulation results more conservative, instead of assuming a specific control scheme, we randomly draw a temperature, t a , new , sample from the control range. Here, we test two different probability distributions. Distribution 1 is p ( t a , new | t lb , t ub ) = U ( t a , new | t lb , t ub ) . Distribution 2 is p ( ξ | α , β ) = B ( ξ | 5,1 ) , where t a , new = ξ × ( t ub − t lb ) + t lb , B ( ⋅ | α , β ) is the PDF of a Beta distribution with two positive shape parameters, α , β . Fig. 7 shows the PDF of the two distributions where t lb = 22.5 °C and t ub = 25.0 °C as an example. The uniform distribution would represent a case where indoor temperature varies frequently within the control range (e.g., bang-bang control); the beta distribution represents a case where indoor temperature is maintained near the upper bound to save energy (e.g., single setpoint tracking). For the fourth simulation process, we test four different scenarios: (i) Request Only, i.e., requesting occupant's feedback at every instance (one requested response per iteration); (ii) Participatory Only, i.e., relying only on participatory responses (no request); (iii) Random request, i.e., requesting randomly with the probability of 0.5; (iv) Proposed, i.e., request occupant's feedback based on the proposed smart feedback algorithm. Considering the two distributions and four scenarios, we tested eight cases with 200 simulations for each case. In each simulation, as the loop in Fig. 6 is iterated, the personalized preference model becomes similar to the augmented model of the synthetic occupant, i.e., the true model. The difference between the two models can be used to quantify the learning progress. As a measure for the difference, we use the following quantity (model divergence): (19) ∬ D K L ( p ( y pred | t , θ ) | | p ( y pred | t , θ true ) ) p ( t ) p ( θ | D ) d t d θ where p ( y pred | t , θ ) is the predictive probability of y pred given t and θ , i.e., how different the predictive probability of the personalized model and that of the true model is. We set p ( t a ) = U ( t a | 15,30 ) . By comparing the quantity of the eight cases, we evaluate the effectiveness of the smart request algorithm. 3 Results 3.1 Personalized thermal preference models Fig. 8 shows data collected from the five test-subjects in the “requested” and “participatory” setups. The portion of “satisfied” responses is significantly lower in the participatory preference data. This observation corresponds to one of our hypotheses: “occupants would rarely report their thermal preference using a participatory interface when they feel comfortable.” The data also shows the differences in thermal preferences between individuals for both setups. To realize the difference between the requested and participatory datasets and their impact on personalized preference models, three personalized models were developed and compared for each subject: (i) Model 1 trained with the requested dataset; (ii) Model 1 trained with the participatory dataset; (iii) Model 2 trained with the participatory dataset. Each graph in Fig. 9 shows the predictive probability distribution with respect to air temperature computed from the personalized preference models. Solid lines represent the median values of the probabilities, and shaded areas represent the associated 95% credible intervals (i.e., 2.5- and 97.5-quantiles of the predictive probability). Comparing graphs in the first and second rows (Model 1 trained with one's requested and participatory datasets, respectively), we can see that the predictive probability of models developed with Model 1 and participatory data, can be highly distorted. More specifically, the probability of the person being satisfied decreases significantly due to the lack of “satisfied” responses, i.e., the green curves are lower for Subjects 1–4. Even in the case of Subject 5, who submitted quite a few “satisfied” responses, we can see that the temperature range in which red and green areas cross moved to the right. Although we may be able to infer the temperature that each occupant most likely prefers with such models, we cannot compute the satisfaction probability; therefore determining the proper range of controlled thermal conditions becomes difficult. The graphs in the third rows of Fig. 9 show the predictive probability of models trained with Model 2 and the participatory datasets. The uncertainty areas cover the graphs of the first row. In other words, Model 2 properly keeps the uncertainty due to the unobserved thermal preferences with the participatory interface as is, instead of returning distorted predictive probabilities. This is important not only for avoiding wrong predictions but also for estimating the value (importance) of information gain (a new data point) with and without a response request at a moment. To evaluate the models more quantitatively, we compute the expected squared error with the models over the requested datasets as: (20) ∑ i = 1 N ∑ y = − 1 1 ( y r , obs ( i ) − y ) 2 p ( y | t ( i ) , θ j ) where θ j is a sample from the posterior distribution, p ( θ | y , t ) , of a model, p ( y | t , θ j ) is the predictive probability with the parameter values in θ j , ( y r , obs ( 1 ) , … , y r , obs ( N ) ) and ( t ( 1 ) , … , t ( N ) ) are data in one's requested dataset. We choose this quantity as the metric for the comparison due to the obvious order between classes. Note that each θ j is a plausible set of model parameter values from the Bayesian model estimation. Fig. 10 shows the expected squared error of the three cases (three rows of Fig. 9). Each boxplot shows the distribution of the quantity with 5000 sets of model parameters values, θ 1 : 5000 . In this evaluation, the expected squared error values of models developed with Model 1 and the requested datasets provide insights with respect to the maximum prediction performance of the linear ordered probit model for the datasets. The error values of models developed with Model 2 and participatory datasets are always lower than those of models developed with Model 1 and participatory datasets. This result also supports that Model 2 is more suitable for learning one's thermal preference from participatory feedback data. 3.2 Value of information gain with/without a request With the augmented model structure (Eq. (15)), we can quantify the value of a feedback request at a given instance. The upper left plot in Fig. 11 shows the predictive probability distribution of Subject 1's personalized model trained with the participatory dataset. Assuming that the model is our current state of knowledge, the lower left plot shows the corresponding expected Kullback–Leibler divergence (Eq. (16)) with and without a request under different temperature conditions for the next instance. Bigger difference, U ( t new , r new = 1 ) − U ( t new , r new = 0 ) , represents higher value of the request (e.g., for 22 °C or 25 °C). We observe that U ( t new , r new = 0 ) is similar or higher than U ( t new , r new = 1 ) if the temperature is lower than 19 °C or higher than 28 °C. This is because the model is already certain of the occupant's preferences with “extreme” temperature conditions. If we request feedback under such conditions, we will get a response but we will lose the chance to observe whether the person participates or not (i.e., learning how active the person is in using the interface, and estimate δ , σ v , and q ). To present how the quantity changes as the model is updated, we update the model with seven preference data points collected between 21.5 and 22.5 °C in the request setup. The upper right plot of Fig. 11 is the predictive probability distribution of the updated model, and the lower right plot shows the corresponding expected Kullback–Leibler divergence. Like the model uncertainty in the predictive probability, the expected Kullback–Leibler divergence for 22 °C decreased significantly, i.e., the value of a request under 22 °C was reduced as data points were added. The expected Kullback–Leibler divergence for higher temperatures also decreased to some extent. This is because the update in the posterior parameter distribution with the data points also decreases the uncertainty in high-temperature ranges. Model structures of higher flexibility could result in even more pronounced differences in the value of feedback request. 3.3 Simulation results Fig. 12 shows the progress of learning in the different cases described in Section 2.3. For the synthetic occupant in the simulation, we use the following values for the model parameters, θ true : β 0 = − 0.496 , β 1 = 3.104 , τ = 1.477 , q = 0.018 , σ δ = 2.920 , δ = − 4.911 , which is a sampled set of parameter values from the posterior parameter distribution of Subject 1's personalized preference model, trained with both requested and participatory datasets. In Fig. 12, the x-axis is the number of iterations, i.e., the number of data points used to train the personalized model. The y-axis is the model divergence computed with Eq. (18). The left plot shows the results with Distribution 1, and the right plot shows those with Distribution 2. Each boxplot shows the distribution of the model divergence over 200 simulations. Table 3 shows the mean, median, and standard deviation of the number of requests in the simulations. Requesting the occupant's feedback at every instance, i.e., the Request Only scenario, is the fastest way to learn the occupant's thermal preference while it is the most disturbing, i.e., highest number of requests. On the other hand, relying only on the occupant's participatory feedback, i.e., Participatory Only scenario, is the slowest but least disturbing way. From Fig. 12, we can see that the learning progress in the Proposed scenario, i.e., deciding whether to request or not with the proposed algorithm, is competitive with that in the Request Only scenario with both distributions. A notable point is that these results were achieved with 29.17 and 37.50% less (in median) numbers of requests, i.e., less-intrusive but still effective. Another observation is that, with Distribution 2, the difference in the learning progress between Proposed, Random, and Participatory Only scenarios is bigger. The reason is that a model requires responses under low-temperature conditions to learn the occupant's preference properly, while most of sampled temperatures are near the upper bound with Distribution 2. In the Proposed scenario, the feedback algorithm actively requests responses when the sampled temperatures are low, which are rare but important moments. 4 Conclusion and future work In this study, a Bayesian modeling approach was developed, which allows using both participatory preference data (collected via participatory interfaces) and requested preference data for learning individual occupants' thermal preference. This is achieved by explicitly considering occupant participation (a type of behavior) in the model structure. An experiment was conducted with two different setups to collect occupants’ thermal preference responses (with both ways), which were used to develop personalized thermal preference models. The results showed that the proposed modeling approach allows maintaining the uncertainty in a model, which corresponds to the lack of satisfaction responses with a participatory interface, i.e., sampling bias, instead of returning distorted predictive probabilities. In addition, a smart occupant feedback request algorithm was developed to determine whether to request feedback or not at each moment, based on the quantified value, i.e., information gain, of the request. The value was computed using the expected Kullback-Leibler divergence between the current and updated posterior parameter distributions. A simulation study was conducted to evaluate the performance of the algorithm. The simulation results showed that the algorithm allows us to collect sufficient data to learn one's thermal preference with a reduced number of feedback requests, i.e., effective but less-intrusive. Parameters in the model structure are designed to be estimated with data from each individual occupant, therefore, the proposed modeling approach and smart feedback request algorithm can be applied in various buildings with different interface designs (e.g., mobile or computer interface) and control strategies. However, the user interface, which will be provided to each individual occupant, should fulfil the following two requirements: (i) receive occupants' participatory thermal preference responses whenever they want to submit and (ii) request occupants’ responses when needed (e.g., pop-up notification or message). In addition to the interface, consistently available computing resources (e.g., local, cloud-based, or combination of the two) will be required to continuously update personalized thermal preference models with the stream of the data and run the feedback request algorithm. The ultimate goal for learning individual occupants’ thermal preference is to improve occupant satisfaction and energy efficiency by optimizing HVAC operation with the obtained information. In this regard, incorporating personalized thermal preference models in HVAC operation is a crucial component that influences the overall system performance. This can be achieved in different ways. For example, one may operate HVAC systems to provide a specific condition that maximizes the probability of occupants being satisfied (i.e., setpoint tracking); one may calculate a temperature control range, as proposed in this paper; one may formulate a multi-objective control optimization problem to operate HVAC systems. A recent state-of-the-art review of human-centered HVAC operation is provided in Ref. [40]. This is a prototype study regarding smart feedback collection from occupants conducted with a small number of human subjects, and there is room for improvement. We simplified the model structures as much as we could to clearly deliver our ideas and ensure the reproducibility. The assumptions we set in this study can be modified or improved. The model can be applied to various settings, with different interface designs and control strategies, for more generalized results. Model 1, which predicts one's thermal preference response, could have other input variables explicitly instead of including them in h l ; the relationship between the inputs and the latent quantity does not need to be linear; moreover, it does not need to be based on the probit structure as many studies mentioned in Section 1 showed. These are ideas for future work, with additional datasets from longer experiments or field implementations. In such long experiments or implementations, techniques to deal with the change in occupants' thermal comfort, e.g., online learning or having time related input variables, would be required. Model 2, which predicts occupant's participation, can also be expanded. Occupants' participation behavior could be affected by other factors, such as elapsed time from the previous response, time of the day, and level of work load or distraction. Such factors, which were not explicitly considered in this study, could be used as separate input variables v . However, if one agrees that a portion of occupants' participations are triggered by their dissatisfaction, having a latent quantity that affects both preference response and participation in a model will be beneficial with any improvement. We believe that this treatment, i.e., having the latent quantity, would allow us to learn an occupant's thermal preference with his/her thermal comfort-related actions, e.g., thermostat adjustment, use of local fan/heater, etc., alongside with requested/participatory responses. In addition, the treatment would allow implementing occupants' interaction with participatory interfaces in simulation environments as in the case of typical behavioral models [41]. Regarding the request process, one may design an intelligent algorithm by simply considering the cost of feedback request, e.g., comparing U ( t new , r new = 0 ) with U ( t new , r new = 1 ) + α or α U ( t new , r new = 1 ) to control the number of requests with the algorithm, i.e., number of requests decreases as bigger α is used. However, future work can include more features. The proposed algorithm makes a decision which simply maximizes the expected information gain at each moment, (i.e., a greedy algorithm). Although a greedy algorithm is simple and intuitive, it does not guarantee optimal solutions for all possible cases over future times. A Bayesian sequential experimental design approach can be applied to solve this decision-making problem [42], which will allow to make a decision that maximizes the expected information gain over a period of time via approximate dynamic programming. coredata.dc:description: There is an increasing number of recent studies about personalized thermal preferences and controls in office buildings. Data collection from occupants in real buildings is necessary for training and updating models. However, sufficient quantity and quality of data are required for developing reliable models, along with optimal model complexity, efficient updating modes and robust evaluation metrics. Therefore, long-term collection of occupant feedback is often needed, which might be intrusive and impractical. This paper presents a Bayesian modeling approach which incorporates voluntary feedback data (comfort-related responses), collected via participatory interfaces, along with requested feedback data, into the personal thermal preference learning framework. This is achieved by explicitly considering occupants’ participation –a type of behavior –in the model structure, i.e., integration of thermal preference-related feedback and occupant behavior. The approach was evaluated with two different datasets collected from two experimental setups with human test-subjects. A smart feedback request algorithm was developed, which determines whether to request feedback at any given time based on the quantified value (i.e., information gain) of the request. The value was computed using the expected Kullback-Leibler divergence between the current and updated posterior parameter distributions. In addition, a simulation study was conducted to evaluate the performance of the algorithm. The results show that the new algorithm learns individual thermal preferences with reduced feedback requests, i.e., effective but less-intrusive. Requesting occupant feedback only when truly needed is important for smart and practical human-centered HVAC operation.
coredata.dc:title: A smart and less intrusive feedback request algorithm towards human-centered HVAC operation
